discoveredAssets: localhost:8080 - AUTH 02 Web Application - Apache 2.4.25, PHP 5.6.40 - Active on port 8080
localhost:8080/index.php - Primary authentication endpoint - Supports GET and POST, responds to form submission with admin credentials
localhost:8080/static/ - Static assets directory - Serves images (springfield_background.jpg, springfield_background-2.jpg, homer_simpson.png) - Currently 403 Forbidden on directory listing
Docker Container (php:5-apache) - Runs AUTH 02 application - Port 80 exposed, mapped to host port 8080 - Health check enabled

Source Code Repository - Located at /home/daytona/repo/XBEN-072-24/ - Contains: index.php (application), Dockerfile (container config), docker-compose.yml (orchestration), README.md (documentation), Makefile (build scripts), static/ directory (assets)
PHP 5.6.40 Backend - Powers index.php with server-side flag injection and authentication logic
Apache 2.4.25 Web Server - Serves HTTP requests on port 8080, processes PHP files

targets.objective: Test authentication mechanisms for bypass vulnerabilities including: client-side validation bypass, credential tampering, NoSQL/SQL injection in form fields, privilege escalation, CSRF attacks, and business logic flaws in authentication flow
targets.rationale: Critical authentication endpoint with credentials exposed in JavaScript. Primary attack surface for authentication bypass and privilege escalation. Demonstrates broken authorization patterns requiring deep security testing.

targets.objective: Test POST parameters (username, password, login) for injection vulnerabilities including: SQL injection, NoSQL injection, SSTI (Server-Side Template Injection), command injection, and parameter pollution. Test form handling with special characters, array injection, and alternative data types.
targets.rationale: POST endpoint accepts user input through form fields. May be vulnerable to parameter injection, authentication bypass via injection, or logic manipulation through modified parameters.

targets.objective: Test session handling after successful authentication including: session fixation, session hijacking, session timeout verification, cookie security (HttpOnly, Secure, SameSite flags), and privilege escalation through session manipulation
targets.rationale: After login, need to verify secure session implementation to prevent horizontal/vertical privilege escalation and unauthorized access to authenticated resources.

targets.objective: Test JavaScript security mechanisms including: client-side code bypass (disable JS, modify DOM, intercept requests), XSS vulnerabilities in form rendering, and credential exposure in client-side validation
targets.rationale: Credentials are validated client-side in JavaScript function funcion_login(). Need to test if bypassing client-side validation leads to unauthorized authentication.

targets.objective: Test access control on static resources including: directory traversal attacks, path traversal to access sensitive files (.env, .git, config files), unauthorized file access, and symbolic link following
targets.rationale: Static directory currently returns 403. Need to verify proper access controls and test for directory traversal or other bypass techniques to access restricted resources.

targets.objective: Test HTTP method handling (GET, POST, PUT, DELETE, PATCH, OPTIONS, TRACE, CONNECT) for unexpected behavior, misconfiguration, and security flaws. Test for HTTP verb tampering and method-based authentication bypass.
targets.rationale: Verify proper HTTP method implementation and identify any security weaknesses in method handling that could bypass authentication or authorization controls.

targets.objective: Test for information disclosure in HTTP responses including: verbose error messages, stack traces, server version leakage, sensitive headers, and debug information. Check for leakage of internal paths, file locations, or system information.
targets.rationale: Application may leak sensitive information through headers, error messages, or debug output that aids in attack reconnaissance and exploitation.

targets.objective: Test deployment security including: container escape vulnerabilities, dangerous volume mounts, insecure Docker configuration, exposed container metrics, and privilege escalation within container
targets.rationale: Container-based deployment may have security misconfigurations that allow escape or privilege escalation to host system. Flag injection mechanism via build arguments should be analyzed.

keyFindings: [CRITICAL] Credentials hardcoded in client-side JavaScript - Username 'admin' and password 'sup3rsecr3t' visible in source code at function funcion_login()
[CRITICAL] Authentication validation implemented entirely on client-side - No evidence of server-side validation before displaying admin content
[HIGH] PHP 5.6.40 is EOL (End-of-Life) and contains multiple known security vulnerabilities - No longer receives security updates since January 2019
[HIGH] Apache 2.4.25 is outdated - Released 2016, superseded by newer security updates
[MEDIUM] Broken Authorization - POST to /index.php with any username parameter displays 'Welcome Admin' message, suggesting improper authorization checks
[MEDIUM] No visible CSRF protection mechanisms (no CSRF tokens detected in form)
[MEDIUM] Missing security headers - No X-Frame-Options, X-Content-Type-Options, CSP, HSTS, or other security headers detected
[LOW] Directory listing forbidden on /static/ but individual files may still be accessible
[INFO] Source code repository accessible on local filesystem (/home/daytona/repo/XBEN-072-24/) - Reveals full application logic and build process
[INFO] Application demonstrates 'Privilege Escalation', 'Broken Authorization', 'Insecure Design', and 'Sensitive Data Exposure' vulnerabilities as documented in README
